definition: Executive-level information security leader responsible for developing, implementing, and maintaining comprehensive information security program meeting GLBA Safeguards Rule requirements. CISO designated as Qualified Individual per Safeguards Rule Element 1, with board-level reporting and authority to enforce security policies.
official_description: Per Safeguards Rule 16 CFR 314.4(a), financial institution must designate qualified individual with responsibility for information security program. CISO (Chief Information Security Officer), Security Officer, or equivalent position designated as Qualified Individual typically. CISO definition: executive-level position with: (1) knowledge of information security and risks, (2) experience with security program development and implementation, (3) authority to enforce security controls, (4) direct reporting to senior management or board, (5) adequate resources and budget for security program, (6) responsibility for all nine Safeguards Rule elements, (7) accountability for security program effectiveness. CISO Qualified Individual Requirements: knowledge and experience in: information security industry practices; organizational risk landscape; institution's systems and data; applicable legal/regulatory requirements; authority to: make security decisions; allocate resources; enforce policies; demand remediation; authority to override business decisions for security reasons; escalate to board; authority to hire/fire security personnel; set security budgets; direct incident response; approval authority for: major security initiatives; vendor security requirements; system changes affecting security; access to: board and senior management; all systems and data; all personnel; external consultants; CISO Board Reporting: annual written report to board or designated senior officer covering: information security program status and effectiveness; risks identified and mitigation status; safeguards implemented; compliance with Safeguards Rule requirements; areas of non-compliance; recommended improvements; funding needs; incident summary; control testing results; risk trends; CISO responsibilities include: Program Design and Implementation: develop comprehensive information security program; ensure nine elements addressed; coordinate implementation across organization; monitor effectiveness; update based on risk assessment; risk-based approach; scalability; Risk Assessment Leadership: oversee periodic risk assessment; coordinate threat identification; assess likelihood and impact; determine safeguard priorities; drive risk-based decisions; establish risk appetite; Administrative Safeguards: develop policies and procedures; establish personnel security; access control governance; training program oversight; incident response plan; change management; configuration management; vendor oversight; Technical Safeguards: encryption standards establishment; MFA implementation; system hardening; patch management; monitoring and logging; security testing; Physical Safeguards: facility access controls; environmental protections; media security; workstation security; disaster recovery; Personnel Management: hiring of security staff; security staff training; delegation of security responsibilities; performance management; succession planning; professional development; Audit and Testing: oversee vulnerability assessments; coordinate penetration testing; manage remediation; audit procedures; internal/external audit coordination; compliance testing; Vendor Management: establish vendor assessment procedures; oversee vendor due diligence; review service provider agreements; monitor vendor compliance; audit vendors; incident response to vendor breaches; Business Continuity: develop disaster recovery plan; backup and recovery procedures; testing and validation; recovery procedures; alternative processing sites; third-party vendor involvement; Incident Response Authority: incident command; response coordination; notification decisions; FTC notification authority; law enforcement coordination; recovery decisions; employee communications; Regulatory Engagement: examiner coordination; examination response; documentation provision; remediation reporting; regulatory relationship; Board and Senior Management Communication: regular security updates; risk reporting; incident communication; budget requests; strategic security planning; assessment of program adequacy; Budget and Resource Allocation: security budget development; spending approval; major initiative funding; staffing needs; external service procurement; technology investments; External Relationships: security consultants; penetration testers; forensics firms; law enforcement; regulatory agencies; industry groups; threat intelligence providers; Information Retention and Documentation: documentation of: program design; risk assessments; safeguard implementation; testing results; audit findings; incidents; remediation; board reporting; Qualified Individual Authority: CISO cannot be subordinate to: Chief Information Officer (to preserve independence); Chief Financial Officer; other non-security executive (CIO may coordinate but CISO reports separately to board); CISO may be sole security officer in small institution; larger institutions have security team reporting to CISO; CISO Qualifications Assessment: institution should assess: relevant experience; technical knowledge; industry certifications (CISSP, CISM); previous CISO roles; educational background; understanding of financial services; Escalation Authority: CISO authority to escalate: directly to board or board committee; bypass normal organizational structure; get immediate attention for urgent issues; incident severity determination; Continuity and Succession: CISO continuity planning: identify succession candidates; cross-train; knowledge transfer; document critical procedures; backup for vacation/absence; CISO departure: transition plan; knowledge transfer; system access revocation; regulatory notification; Examination Focus: examiners assess: CISO authority and independence; CISO qualifications; board reporting; resource allocation; program effectiveness; incident response; Board Oversight: board responsibility for: CISO oversight; security strategy approval; budget approval; major decision approval; risk tolerance setting; regular reporting reception; Regulatory Examination: examiners evaluate: CISO independence; qualifications; authority; reporting lines; board access; resource adequacy; decision-making authority

definition: Executive-level compliance leader responsible for developing, implementing, and maintaining enterprise compliance program ensuring GLBA compliance across all domains (privacy, security, pretexting prevention, vendor management, breach response). CCO reports to General Counsel and Board Compliance Committee, overseeing all GLBA compliance functions.
official_description: Chief Compliance Officer (CCO), Compliance Officer, or equivalent position responsible for enterprise-wide compliance governance. CCO definition: executive-level position with: (1) knowledge of GLBA and other applicable regulations, (2) experience with compliance program development, (3) authority independent from business units, (4) direct reporting to senior management and board, (5) adequate resources and budget for compliance, (6) responsibility for all compliance domains, (7) accountability for compliance program effectiveness. CCO independent authority ensures compliance not subordinated to business pressures. CCO Responsibilities: GLBA Compliance Program: develop comprehensive GLBA compliance program; policies and procedures; governance structure; compliance framework; compliance risk assessment; Enterprise Compliance Governance: compliance committee structure; cross-functional coordination; compliance oversight; audit coordination; examination preparation; Regulation P (Privacy Rule) Oversight: privacy notice development and compliance; opt-out program administration; information sharing governance; consumer rights management; privacy impact assessments; Privacy Officer relationship: coordinates with Privacy Officer (may be same person or separate); GLBA Safeguards Rule Oversight: works with CISO on security compliance; nine elements addressed; safeguard testing and validation; incident response compliance; Pretexting Prevention Oversight: identity verification procedures; employee training; suspicious request detection; incident investigation; compliance with Section 521; Vendor/Third-Party Management: vendor risk management oversight; service provider agreement requirements; due diligence coordination; monitoring procedures; audit rights; Breach Response and Notification: develops breach response procedures; FTC notification requirements (30-day deadline); state consumer notification requirements; incident response testing; notification procedures; Training and Awareness: compliance training program; annual training; role-based training; effectiveness measurement; training documentation; Regulatory Relationships: examiner relationships; regulatory correspondence; examination responses; regulatory guidance updates; regulatory change monitoring; Audit Coordination: internal audit relationships; external audit coordination; audit planning; finding tracking; remediation verification; Examination Preparation: examination readiness; documentation organization; key personnel preparation; examination process coordination; Issue Management: compliance issues identification; finding tracking; remediation planning; remediation verification; escalation authority; Board Reporting: compliance status reporting; examination findings; regulatory changes; remediation status; compliance risks; risk appetite alignment; Regulatory Monitoring: GLBA changes; FTC guidance updates; banking regulator guidance; state law changes; enforcement actions; emerging issues; Documentation and Records: compliance documentation; policy documentation; training records; examination documentation; finding remediation; Board Compliance Committee Relationship: committee support; agenda development; reporting; recommendations; Board Access: direct board access; regular board meetings; committee reporting; escalation authority; Compensation and Budget: compliance budget development; resource allocation; compliance tool investment; training budget; external counsel; Enforcement of Compliance: policies; violation investigation; discipline procedures; escalation for serious violations; remediation requirements; Independence: CCO independence: reporting line not through business units; authority to investigate; authority to mandate compliance; ability to report examination findings; ability to decline business decisions for compliance reasons; CCO Qualifications: legal background typical but not required; GLBA expertise; compliance program experience; regulation and examination knowledge; industry certifications (CCP - Certified Compliance Professional); Compliance Skills: policy development; governance; audit coordination; regulatory knowledge; risk assessment; documentation; communication; Leadership: executive presence; authority; credibility; cross-functional influence; board-level communication; Change Management: policy updates; communication of changes; training on changes; implementation oversight; effectiveness verification

definition: Executive or senior-level privacy leader responsible for developing and implementing GLBA Financial Privacy Rule (Regulation P) compliance program, including privacy notice development, opt-out program administration, consumer rights management, and privacy impact assessments. Reports to Chief Compliance Officer or General Counsel.
official_description: Privacy Officer (or Chief Privacy Officer, Data Protection Officer) responsible for GLBA Financial Privacy Rule compliance. Privacy Officer definition: executive or senior-level position with: (1) knowledge of privacy laws (GLBA, state privacy laws, GDPR), (2) experience with privacy program development, (3) authority to enforce privacy policies, (4) reporting to Chief Compliance Officer or General Counsel, (5) adequate resources and budget for privacy, (6) responsibility for all privacy compliance domains, (7) accountability for privacy program effectiveness. Privacy Officer role includes: Privacy Notice Management: develop privacy notices: initial notice at account opening; annual notice (unless FAST Act exemption); revised notice for material changes; model form compliance (FTC model); content compliance (six required disclosures); plain language; clear and conspicuous; notice delivery: paper, electronic, combined method; retention of evidence; Opt-Out Program Administration: develop opt-out procedures; reasonable methods (phone, mail, online); minimum 30-day opt-out period; honor and track opt-outs; revocation procedures; annual reminder of rights; affiliate marketing opt-out (if applicable); joint marketing coordination; Consumer Rights Management: consumer access requests: verification of identity; timely response; dispute procedures; complaint investigation; consumer communication; Consumer Privacy Policies: documenting: information collection practices; information use practices; information sharing practices; consumer rights; safeguards protecting information; Privacy Impact Assessments: conduct for new products/services; assess privacy implications; identify risks; mitigation strategy; documentation; Information Sharing Governance: establish policies limiting sharing to permissible purposes; affiliate sharing policies; non-affiliate sharing restrictions; service provider data use restrictions; third-party relationships management; Privacy by Design: integrate privacy into new products/services; minimize information collection; implement privacy controls; development team coordination; Customer Communication: educate customers on privacy rights; explain information practices; transparency; accessible privacy policies; Privacy Training: develop training for personnel handling customer information; emphasize privacy rights; explain policies; Privacy Policy Development: comprehensive privacy policy; board approval; periodic update; communication to stakeholders; GLBA Requirement Updates: monitor for guidance changes; implement updates; policy amendments; training updates; Regulatory Examination Preparation: prepare for FTC or banking regulator privacy examination; maintain documentation; respond to inquiries; remediate deficiencies; State Privacy Laws: manage California CCPA, Virginia VCDPA, other state requirements; state-specific privacy rights; disclosure requirements; opt-out requirements; Multi-State Coordination: coordinate privacy requirements across states where institution operates; compliance with most stringent requirement; Privacy Governance: privacy committee; cross-functional coordination; business unit engagement; Compliance Reporting: regular reporting to Chief Compliance Officer; board reporting on privacy matters; examination findings; Privacy Budget: privacy program budget; staffing; training; external resources; technology; Privacy Risk Assessment: assess privacy risks: unauthorized disclosure; data accuracy; consumer harm; risk prioritization; mitigation planning; Third-Party Privacy Management: vendor privacy requirements; privacy clauses in service provider agreements; data processor requirements; breach notification; audit rights; Consumer Complaint Handling: receive and investigate privacy complaints; respond; escalate as needed; track trends; improve processes; Privacy Documentation: maintain: privacy policies; notice examples; consent forms; audit trails of privacy decisions; Consumer Access Rights: manage requests for information consumers have on file; verify identity; provide information; discuss disputes; Privacy Dispute Resolution: handle disputes about accuracy; consumer claims of violation; investigation; resolution; Communication to Consumers: explain privacy practices; rights; breaches; data handling; Regulatory Reporting: report to FTC if required; state attorney general; regulatory filings; Board Relationship: regular board reporting; governance oversight; strategic decisions; budget approval; Privacy Committee: establish privacy committee; regular meetings; review policies; identify issues; Leadership Skills: executive presence; authority; business unit relationships; stakeholder engagement; Communication Skills: plain language communication; technical to non-technical translation; clear policy writing; consumer-friendly materials; Industry Leadership: participate in privacy forums; contribute to best practices; thought leadership; professional development; Professional Certifications: consider privacy certifications (CIPP - Certified Information Privacy Professional); GDPR experience; legal background helpful but not required

definition: Information technology audit professional responsible for assessing and testing information security controls, GLBA safeguard implementation, vulnerability assessments, penetration testing, and IT audit procedures. May be internal audit staff or external IT audit firm engaged for independent assessment.
official_description: Qualified IT Auditor (or Information Security Auditor, IT Audit Manager) responsible for IT audit and security control assessment. Qualified IT Auditor definition: professional with: (1) IT audit expertise, (2) information security knowledge, (3) understanding of GLBA safeguards, (4) ability to conduct independent assessment, (5) audit procedures expertise, (6) reporting to Chief Audit Executive (internal audit director), (7) independence from IT operations and business units, (8) responsibility for security control testing. IT Auditor Responsibilities: Security Control Assessment: evaluate technical safeguards: encryption implementation; access controls; network security; application security; system hardening; Audit Procedures: test controls for effectiveness; verify configuration; assess design and operation; document findings; Vulnerability Assessment Oversight: oversee vulnerability scanning; assess scan quality; evaluate scan results; prioritize findings; remediation tracking; Penetration Testing Oversight: plan penetration testing; coordinate with external pen testers (if used); evaluate test results; assess implications; test recommendations; Access Control Testing: verify access controls functioning; test role-based access; verify segregation of duties; review access logs; test deprovisioning; Encryption Verification: verify encryption implementation; test encryption algorithms; assess key management; assess encryption in transit; assess encryption at rest; Patch Management Testing: verify patch deployment; test patch effectiveness; assess patch timeliness; review patch exceptions; System Configuration Review: review security baselines; verify hardening; assess secure configurations; identify deviations; Log Analysis: review audit logs; assess logging completeness; verify log retention; assess log security; Wireless Network Assessment: if applicable, assess wireless security; WPA encryption; authentication; rogue access point detection; Data Classification Review: verify data classification accuracy; assess appropriate controls per classification; Multi-Factor Authentication Testing: verify MFA implementation; test factor types; assess phishing resistance; Vendor Security Assessment: for critical vendors, conduct independent assessment; review vendor controls; assess vendor testing; document findings; Business Continuity Testing: evaluate disaster recovery procedures; test backup restoration; assess recovery timelines; verify RPO/RTO; Incident Response Testing: test incident response procedures; evaluate detection capabilities; assess containment procedures; evaluate notification procedures; Compliance Assessment: assess GLBA safeguard compliance; identify gaps; assess remediation status; Audit Documentation: document: audit procedures; testing results; findings; remediation recommendations; evidence of testing; Audit Reports: prepare comprehensive audit reports: findings; severity assessment; recommendations; remediation timelines; Reporting: reports to Chief Audit Executive (internal audit); findings reported independently; management response tracked; Board Reporting: significant findings escalated to audit committee or board; audit results discussed; remediation tracking; External Audit Coordination: if external auditors engaged, coordinate; avoid duplicate work; share findings; assess external recommendations; Independence: critical for IT audit; must not report to IT management; must not be influenced by business unit pressures; should have escalation path to audit committee; Fraud Detection: assess controls for fraud prevention; evaluate detective controls; assess monitoring for fraud indicators; Regulatory Examination Support: provide examination support; respond to examiner requests; provide documentation; explain audit results; Professional Standards: follow: ISACA standards (COBIT, CISA); IIA standards (International Internal Audit Standards); GAAS (Generally Accepted Auditing Standards); Risk-Based Approach: focus on highest-risk systems; critical systems; high-impact controls; Resource Constraints: balance audit scope with available resources; prioritize high-risk areas; use sampling; Continuous Auditing: assess need for continuous or real-time auditing; implement automated auditing tools where feasible; Certifications: professional certifications valuable: CISA (Certified Information Systems Auditor); CIA (Certified Internal Auditor); CRISC (Certified in Risk and Information Systems Control); CISSP (Certified Information Systems Security Professional); Training: ongoing professional training; updated on new threats; emerging audit issues; technology changes; Emerging Audit Issues: assess new technologies; cloud computing audit; AI/machine learning; blockchain; API security; Follow-up: track remediation of findings; verify completion; re-assess controls after remediation

definition: Executive-level audit leader responsible for managing internal audit function, conducting GLBA compliance audits, risk assessment audits, IT security audits, and providing independent assurance to board on organizational compliance and risk management. Reports directly to Board Audit Committee.
official_description: Internal Audit Director (Chief Audit Executive, Audit Manager) responsible for internal audit function. Internal Audit Director definition: executive position with: (1) audit expertise, (2) GLBA compliance knowledge, (3) independence from business operations, (4) direct reporting to board audit committee, (5) adequate resources and budget for audit, (6) authority to audit all areas, (7) responsibility for audit plan and execution, (8) accountability for audit quality. Audit Independence: critical requirement; cannot report to: CEO, CFO, operations management; should report to board audit committee; should have escalation authority to board; charter defining independence and authority. Internal Audit Responsibilities: Annual Audit Planning: develop annual audit plan: risk-based audit approach; audit scope; testing procedures; staffing; timeline; board approval; GLBA Compliance Audit: comprehensive audit of GLBA compliance: privacy notice compliance; opt-out procedures; safeguards implementation; breach notification procedures; pretexting prevention; Risk Assessment Audit: assess institution's risk management: risk identification; risk assessment procedures; risk mitigation; risk governance; Privacy Compliance Audit: assess privacy compliance: privacy notices; opt-out program; consumer rights; information sharing; Information Security Audit: assess information security program: policies; risk assessment; safeguards; monitoring; testing; incident response; Third-Party Risk Audit: assess vendor management: due diligence; contracts; monitoring; audit procedures; Fraud Prevention Audit: assess fraud detection and prevention: internal controls; fraud indicators; prevention procedures; Audit Testing: conduct testing per audit plan: control testing; compliance testing; evidence gathering; documentation; Sampling: use statistical sampling for efficiency; large populations; transaction testing; Audit Procedures: design and implement audit procedures; documentation of procedures; evidence of execution; Findings and Recommendations: document findings: control deficiencies; non-compliance; risks; recommendations for remediation; Audit Reports: prepare comprehensive audit reports: findings; severity; risk assessment; recommendations; management response; Board Reporting: regular reporting to audit committee: audit progress; significant findings; management responses; remediation tracking; Management Communication: report findings to management: discussion of findings; opportunity for response; management response tracking; Audit Committee Coordination: audit committee oversight; meeting attendance; communication; examination response; Compliance with Audit Standards: comply with: ISACA COSO framework; IIA audit standards; GAAS; audit quality standards; External Audit Coordination: if external auditor engaged: coordination; avoid duplication; share findings; external auditor recommendations; Compliance with Professional Standards: follow: IIA International Standards for Professional Practice of Internal Auditing; GAAS; ISACA standards; Internal Audit Charter: develop and maintain audit charter: audit authority; audit scope; reporting lines; independence; resource allocation; Professional Development: staff training; certification (CIA); emerging audit issues; technology training; Staffing: audit staff management: hiring; training; performance evaluation; professional development; succession planning; Audit Tools and Technology: implement audit tools: sampling; CAATS (Computer-Assisted Audit Techniques); data analytics; continuous auditing; Budget and Resources: audit budget; staffing; training; tools; external resources; Continuous Audit: assess need for continuous or real-time audit; implementation of automated audit procedures; Examination Preparation: prepare for regulatory examination; organize audit documentation; respond to examiner requests; Audit Documentation: maintain: audit plans; audit procedures; audit evidence; audit reports; findings; management responses; Remediation Tracking: track management remediation: issue resolution; timeline; reassessment; Board Escalation: escalate significant findings: to board or audit committee; recommendations for action; Follow-up Testing: verify management remediation: re-test controls; confirm closure; document completion; Quality Assurance: assess audit quality; peer review; external quality assessment; Performance Measurement: measure audit effectiveness; audit findings vs. actual incidents; audit impact; Fraud Investigation Support: support fraud investigations; provide audit evidence; background investigation; Professional Ethics: ethical conduct; objectivity; independence; confidentiality

definition: Board-level committee responsible for governance oversight of organizational risks, including GLBA compliance, information security, privacy, regulatory requirements, and risk management. Committee reports directly to full Board of Directors on risk management effectiveness.
official_description: Board Risk Committee (or Audit and Risk Committee, Compliance Committee) is board-level committee responsible for oversight of organizational risks. Committee definition: board committee with: (1) board member composition, (2) independent members (independent from management), (3) financial literacy and risk expertise, (4) authority to request information, (5) regular meetings, (6) reporting to full board, (7) responsibility for risk governance, (8) accountability for risk framework. Committee structure: typically 3-5 board members; financial services experience; independent directors preferred; executive sessions without management; Audit Committee or separate Risk Committee or combined. Board Risk Committee Responsibilities: GLBA Compliance Oversight: monitor GLBA compliance; approve compliance program; receive compliance reporting; address compliance gaps; Risk Assessment Oversight: receive and discuss risk assessment results; validate risk prioritization; ensure mitigations in place; Security Program Oversight: approve information security program; ensure adequate resources; receive security reporting; incident awareness; receive annual security report from Qualified Individual; Privacy Program Oversight: approve privacy policies; privacy notice review; opt-out program oversight; consumer complaint trends; Cybersecurity Risk Management: assess cyber risks; ensure detection and response capability; business continuity; incident response capability; Third-Party Risk Management: oversee vendor risk management; critical vendor oversight; service provider incidents; Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery: ensure capability exists; receive testing results; discuss recovery timelines; Regulatory Relationships: aware of regulatory examination schedule; examination findings discussed; remediation status; regulatory changes; Risk Appetite and Risk Tolerance: establish organizational risk appetite; set risk tolerance levels; ensure compliance with defined appetite; Major Decisions Review: review major decisions for risk implications: new products; expansion; technology changes; strategic initiatives; Audit Coordination: receive internal and external audit results; ensure adequate follow-up; track audit findings; Compliance Reporting: receive regular compliance reporting from CCO; examination findings; regulatory changes; issue tracking; Executive Session: meet without management; board-only discussions; candid risk assessment; Board Communication: regular board reporting; escalation of significant issues; Board Member Training: training on: GLBA; emerging cyber risks; financial services regulations; examination process; Meeting Frequency: regular meetings (at least quarterly); more frequent if issues identified; Minutes and Documentation: meeting documentation; decisions recorded; action items tracked; External Advisor Engagement: may engage external consultants: IT security experts; compliance advisors; legal counsel; compensation consultants; Board Compensation Alignment: ensure executive compensation aligns with risk management; incentives for compliance; Financial Services Expertise: committee members should have: GLBA knowledge; cybersecurity awareness; financial services experience; risk management training; Succession Planning: ensure continuity of governance: rotation of members; training of new members; knowledge transfer; Independence Assessment: ensure member independence: no management conflicts; no business unit relationships; ability to make independent decisions; Escalation Authority: authority to escalate directly to full board; emergency convening; crisis management; Examination Coordination: aware of examination schedule; examination outcomes; examination remediation; Communication with Management: regular communication: expectations; concerns; reporting requirements; Information Access: unrestricted access to: audit reports; compliance documentation; risk assessments; testing results; incident information; Strategic Risk Governance: long-term risk management strategy; emerging risks monitoring; market risk assessment; Emerging Issues Awareness: aware of: emerging cyber threats; regulatory changes; industry incidents; lessons learned; Board Education: continuing education on: GLBA updates; cybersecurity trends; risk management practices; industry issues
